elements.content: Four low-dimensional coordination polymers, [Zn2(bpdc)2(dib)2] n ·nH2O (1), [Zn(bpdc)(phen)] n ·2nH2O (2), [Zn(bpdc)(bpy)] n ·2nH2O (3), and [Zn(bpdc)(H2O)] n (4), (H2bpdc = biphenyl-3,4′-dicarboxylic acid, dib = 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-2-yl)butane, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine), have been successfully prepared under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, single crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and luminescence analyses. Self-assembly behaviors of these polymers were entirely directed by N-donor ancillary coligands (bridging or chelating). Complex 1 displays an interesting novel two-dimensional (2D) basketwork, in which Zn(II) ions are knitted by both organic molecules, biphenyl-3,4′-dicarboxylic acid and 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-2-yl)butane, to form an infinite network. Polymers 2 and 3 are infinite zigzag helical chains, and both terminated ligands in 2 and 3 prevent self-assembly to higher dimensional polymers. In 4, a water molecule occupies one of four coordinated positions of Zn(II), and it shows an infinite alternating subloop chains consisting of 8- and 24-membered rings. New coordination modes of the rarely used 3,4-bpdc ligand are reported in 1−4. The results reveal that different secondary building units could tune the process of self-assembly to form low-dimensional structures, and the observed structural motifs can be well regulated by the different chelating or bridging N-donor ancillary ligands. Moreover, complexes 1−4 exhibit strong solid-state luminescence emissions at room temperature.

elements.content: The field of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted tremendous attention owing to their intriguing structural motifs, morphologies, and potential applications as catalysis, optoelectronic, magnetic and luminescent materials. The synthesis of metal−organic frameworks can be influenced by many factors such as the nature of metal ions and linkers, conditions of reactions, counterions, as well as molecular interactions including hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions that can be used to govern the process of self-assembly. Employing appropriate bridging ligands can connect metal ions in different modes and provide possible ways to achieve more robust polymeric structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted tremendous attention owing to their intriguing structural motifs, morphologies, and potential applications as catalysis, optoelectronic, magnetic and luminescent materials. The synthesis of metal-organic frameworks can be influenced by many factors such as the nature of metal ions and linkers, conditions of reactions, counterions, as well as molecular interactions including hydrogen bonds and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions that can be used to govern the process of self-assembly. Employing appropriate bridging ligands can connect metal ions in different modes and provide possible ways to achieve more robust polymeric structures.

elements.content: The carboxylate groups with diverse coordination modes, such as monodentate terminal and bridging, bidentate chelating and bridging, have been widely used as building blocks in construction of the coordination frameworks. On the basis of these designs, more and more researchers use symmetrical and unsymmetrical substitutional carboxylate linkers in order to obtain novel coordination polymer architectures. For example, symmetrical biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate has been focused on, and the crystal structures of its complexes have been well studied, involving many metal ions such as Zn, Cd, Fe, Co, Ni, Pt, Ru, Cu, Cr, Ca, Li, rare earth, etc. In contrast to complexes of symmetrical biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate, complexes with an unsymmetrical biphenyl-3,4′-dicarboxylate are rare. Up to 2010, only two papers reported structures of Cu complexes with this unsymmetrical ligand from the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). With this background in mind, we designed and attempted the assembly of coordination polymers using the bridging linker with unsymmetrical carboxylate groups in coordination-driven self-assembly, and it should allow us to access some novel structural types and interesting properties.

elements.content: Employing various ancillary ligands especially those neutral N-donor coligands to construct coordination polymers is also one of the most efficient and widely utilized approaches in the self-assembly of organic and inorganic hybrid compounds. Generally, long linkers are good candidates for the assembly of interpenetrated structures due to their propensity to form large voids. When a larger ligand was introduced simultaneously, the resulting nets usually assumed uncommon types of entanglements. From this regard, we make use of long 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-2-yl)butane (dib) as a secondary building ligand in our synthetic strategy. Because of its flexibility and conformational freedom from a -(CH2)4- spacer, we expect that the integration of it may offer new opportunities to construct new types of entangled frames. Meanwhile, owing to the termination effect of chelating ligands, such coordination polymers containing both carboxylates and chelating ligands are usually only one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymers. Unaffectedly, to control the architecture and dimensionality of the coordination polymers, both chelating agents 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) and 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) were also as secondary building ligands. We here report a study of self-assembly in Zn ions, biphenyl-3,4′-dicarboxylate, and several secondary building ligands, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, four zinc(II) coordination polymers based on 3,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate, [Zn2(bpdc)2(dib)2] n ·nH2O (1), [Zn(bpdc)(phen)] n ·2nH2O (2), [Zn(bpdc)(bpy)] n ·2nH2O (3), and [Zn(bpdc)(H2O)] n (4), are first synthesized successfully, which display distinct supramolecular architectures under the chelating or flexible bridging N-donor auxiliary coligands. Fluorescence and thermal stability have been carried out on these crystalline materials.

elements.content: All the reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. IR spectra were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument in 4000−400 cm−1 region using KBr pellets. PXRD patterns were collected on a SCXminiFlex II X’pert PRO diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) at 30 kV and 15 mA. The simulated pattern of 1−4 was derived from free Mercury Version 2.2 software. A NETZSCH STA 449C thermogravimetric analyzer was used to obtain thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves in N2 at a ramp rate of 10 K/min in the 303−1073 K region, with an empty Al2O3 crucible being used as the reference. Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed on a Varian Fluorescence Spectrometer Cary Eclipse. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. IR spectra were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument in 4000-400 cm-1 region using KBr pellets. PXRD patterns were collected on a SCXminiFlex II X'pert PRO diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) at 30 kV and 15 mA. The simulated pattern of 1-4 was derived from free Mercury Version 2.2 software. A NETZSCH STA 449C thermogravimetric analyzer was used to obtain thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves in N2 at a ramp rate of 10 K/min in the 303-1073 K region, with an empty Al2O3 crucible being used as the reference. Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed on a Varian Fluorescence Spectrometer Cary Eclipse. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of 0.02 mmol of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O, 0.02 mmol of 3,4′-H2dbc, 0.02 mmol of secondary building ligands dib 1 (phen 2, bpy 3, water 4), and 0.05 mL of 4 M NaOH in H2O, in 2 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Parr Teflon-lined vessel. This vessel was heated to 433 K under autogenous pressure for 48 h and slowly cooled to ambient temperature. Light yellow block crystals for 1−4 were produced, respectively. They were collected and washed with H2O and ethanol, followed by drying in air at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complexes 1-4 

A mixture of 0.02 mmol of Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O, 0.02 mmol of 3,4'-H2dbc, 0.02 mmol of secondary building ligands dib 1 (phen 2, bpy 3, water 4), and 0.05 mL of 4 M NaOH in H2O, in 2 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Parr Teflon-lined vessel. This vessel was heated to 433 K under autogenous pressure for 48 h and slowly cooled to ambient temperature. Light yellow block crystals for 1-4 were produced, respectively. They were collected and washed with H2O and ethanol, followed by drying in air at room temperature.

elements.content:
Coordination mode of bpdc: 4 3311 01

X-ray Crystallographic Studies

Single crystals of compounds 1−4 were glued on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods with the SHELX-97 programs and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. The positions of H atoms were generated geometrically and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. H atoms of lattice water in 1−3 and coordinational water molecules in 4 were located from difference Fourier maps and their global U iso value refined. The final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on observed reflections and variable parameters. Crystal data and structure determination summaries for 1−4 are listed in Table . Coordinated geometries of complexes 1−4 are listed in Table .

As shown in Scheme , hydrothermal processes of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O and 3,4′-H2bpdc with or without secondary building ligands (flexible dib, rigid phen and bpy) and NaOH at 433 K afforded yellow block crystals (1, 4), and needle crystals (2, 3) as single-phase products (as verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD); see ). The complexes do not dissolve in water and most of the common solvents. The IR spectra of 1−4 show strong absorption bands at 1350 and 1600 cm−1, which were assigned to the coordinated carboxylate group. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 cm −1 to ∼1200 cm −1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the aromatic rings of the dib, phen, bpy, and bpdc moieties. The broad band of ∼3450 cm −1 belongs to the typical bands of the O−H stretching modes within the free water. PXRD (see ) patterns are consistent with simulated conditions using single crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

As shown in Scheme , hydrothermal processes of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O and 3,4'-H2bpdc with or without secondary building ligands (flexible dib, rigid phen and bpy) and NaOH at 433 K afforded yellow block crystals (1, 4), and needle crystals (2, 3) as single-phase products (as verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD); see ). The complexes do not dissolve in water and most of the common solvents. The IR spectra of 1-4 show strong absorption bands at 1350 and 1600 cm-1, which were assigned to the coordinated carboxylate group. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 cm -1 to ~1200 cm -1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the aromatic rings of the dib, phen, bpy, and bpdc moieties. The broad band of ~3450 cm -1 belongs to the typical bands of the O-H stretching modes within the free water. PXRD (see ) patterns are consistent with simulated conditions using single crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: It is well-known that the structural geometry could be controlled and modulated by selecting an appropriate second ligand. In compounds 1−3, the Zn ion was first connected by bpdc to wave chain subunits, which were further connected by the flexible briding or rigid chelating N-donor coligands to form a 2D or 1D final structure. In compound 4, each Zn ion is coordinated by three bpdc with a mode of graph 4 3311 01 and one water ions; furthermore, due to the lack of flexible dib or terminate ligands, Zn and bpdc ions made two loop-shaped geometrical subunits of 8- and 24-membered rings and formed infinite alternating subloop chains.

elements.clean_text:
Description of Structures and Topological Analysis

Complex 1 is a supramolecular structure constructed from a 2D layer [Zn2(bpdc)2(dib)2] n ⋅nH2O via hydrogen bonds. Crystallographically, there are two kinds of unique Zn cations, bpdc anions and dib ligands in 1. As shown in Figure , both Zn centers exhibit the same coordination geometries, in which Zn cations locate at distorted tetrahedral geometries and are four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bpdc ligands with Zn-O distances in the range of 1.967(2)-1.986(2) Å and two nitrogen atoms from two dib ligands with Zn-N distances in range of 2.008(2)-2.035(2) Å.

elements.content: In compound 1, the bpdc displayed one coordination mode 4 3210 01 and each bpdc anion coordinated to two Zn(II) centers with Zn1···Zn2 (linker O1/O3) and Zn2C···Zn1 (linker O8/O5, code: C 1 + x, 1 + y, −1 + z) distances of 13.299(3) and 13.306(3) Å, respectively. Both dib ligands in 1 show two conformations (Figure ): one is an arciform dib molecule coordinated to two Zn1 and Zn2 cations with Zn1···Zn2 distances of 9.5398(2) Å, and the other stiff-arm dib molecules linked between both same label Zn ions with Zn1···Zn1 and Zn2···Zn2 distances of 13.530(3) and 14.188(3) Å, respectively. The latter were also nodes of 1D chains consisting of the bpdc ligands.

elements.content: Obviously, Zn ions and both organic linkers (bpdc and dib) make up a double-layer 2D structure (Figure ). Topological analysis of this 2D structure indicates that both Zn ions are all tetrahedral nodes with a Schläfli symbol of 44.62. Interestingly, the double-layer 2D structure is weaved by flexible dibs, forming a basketwork and not being a simple latticework. Namely, the flexible stiff-arm dibs connected Zn ions located on a double layer.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , there are weak interactions between sheets and free water. The distance of π···π interactions between two benzene planes of two bpdc groups in adjacent layers is 3.835(2) Å (Figure a, Table ). The adjacent 2D layers are further linked to each other by C−H···O hydrogen bonds (Figure b, Table ). There are hydrogen bonds involved in O2 and O7 atoms between adjacent layers (Figure b). The distances of C36···O2 and C29···O7 in these weak hydrogen bonds are 3.058(4) and 3.131(4) Å, respectively, with the angles of O2···H36···C36 and O7···H29···C29 in 153° and 146°. There are hydrogen bond interactions between O9 (free H2O molecule) and O6 (carboxylate oxygen) atoms (layer···H2O···layer), with an O6···O9 distance of 2.828(4) Å, O9···O4 of 2.861(5) Å, respectively. The angles of O6···H9A···O9 and O9···H9B···O4 are 174° and 159° (Figure d, Table ).

Employing rigid secondary building units, phen and bpy, we constructed lower dimensional coordination polymers. As illustrated in Figures and , X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that that compounds 2 and 3 are all 1D helical polymeric coordination chains. In the building unit of 2, the zinc center adopts a square pyramid geometry by coordinated oxygen atoms (O1, O2, and O4) of chelating carboxylate groups from two bpdc ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) of phen ligand (Figure a). The O−Zn−O bite angles of the chelating carboxylate groups are small (O2−Zn1−O1 57.1(2)°), and the Zn−O distances are asymmetric (the differences in Zn−O lengths being larger than 0.3 Å), which leads to the square pyramid coordination geometry of the metal ion being badly distorted. The distance of Zn···Zn with 13.592 in 2 and 13.790 Å in 3 separated by bpdc anions. Each bpdc with a graph 4 3211 10 of coordination mode served as a bisconnector to link Zn2+ into 1D infinite helical chains running along the c-axis. The centrosymmetric lattice of 2 is enantiotropic of parallel right- and left-handed helical chains (Figure b). There are a lot of guest water molecules in 2 (Figure c). In compound 3, the 1D helical chains are similar to compound 2. The centrosymmetric lattice of 3 is also enantiotropic of parallel right- and left-handed helical chains (Figure a−c).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the P21/c space group with a 1D coordination chain along the a axis, and its unsymmetrical unit consists of one Zn(II) cation, one bpdc anion, and one coordinated water molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by O atoms from carboxylate groups from three bpdc ligands and a coordinated water with a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distances of Zn−O bonds are in the range of 1.926(2)−2.016(2) Å. There are two kinds of chains along or against the a axis (Figure c). Each bpdc coordinates to three different Zn(II) centers with a graph 4 3311 01 of coordination mode. Compared with zigzag helical chains of complexes 2 and 3, complex 4 has an infinite alternating subloop chain consisting of 8- and 24-membered rings (Figure ).

elements.content: In the 3D lattice, each polymer chain is surrounded by six others through O−H···O hydrogen bonds. Four of them are in the same direction and two of them are in the opposite direction. Namely, the two coordinated water molecules (O5) in each Zn2-dicarboxylate unit contributes four H atoms as donors to link to four uncoordinated carboxylate O2 atoms from four parallel chains, with the hydrogen bond distances and angles of O5···O2 being 2.700(3), 2.744(3) Å and 164(4), 167(4)°, respectively. In the same way, each uncoordinated O2 atom of carboxylate as an acceptor also links coordinated water molecule from antiparallel chains. Thus, 3D crystal pack were formed by the hydrogen bonding interactions (Figure b,c, Table ).

elements.content: The crystal structures of complexes 1−4 indicate that under the synthesis conditions of this work, bpdc acted as a bridge linking Zn(II) ions and formed an infinite chain polymer. In the prescription of the synthesis, employing a flexible bridging dib or rigid chelating phen (bpy) or water ligands results in an interesting 2D basketwork and 1D helical chain or alternating subloop chain topological structures. In other words, secondary building units may tune the process of self-assembly to form low-dimensional structures. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed three new coordinated modes (suggested graph 4 3210 01,4 3211 10 and 4 3311 01) of the 3,4′-bpdc participated in crystal growth except 4 3411 11.

elements.content: To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (Figure ). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1−4 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 K/min.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (Figure ). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1-4 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 K/min.

elements.content: The TGA curve (Figure A) of 1 indicates the release of a guest water molecule from 353 to 473 K (observed 1.7%, calcd 1.78%) to give the product of water-free [Zn2(bpdc)2(dib)2], which is stable up to 593 K, implying that the free water molecules could not be released before 473 K due to the hydrogen bonds by free water molecules. Then the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 593−1073 K. The weak interactions and hydrogen bonds between adjacent layers led to 1 to be stable up to 593 K. For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of free water molecules was observed from 303 to 382 K (obsd 6.69%, calcd 6.89%). The anhydrous composition begins to decompose at 593 K (Figure B), which indicates that the 1D chain formulated as Zn(bpdc)(phen) is stable below 593 K. For 3, the first weight loss of 4.12% from 353 to 423 K is in accordance with the loss of a free water molecule (calculated: 4.44%), while the second weight loss of 78.8% from 438 to 1063 K corresponds to the decomposition of 3. Thermogravimetric analyses of 4 revealed that no weight loss appears during 303 to 433 K, and the first weight loss occurs (5.56%) corresponding well to the release of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 5.57%) from 433 to 531 K. Probably due to the existence of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions in compound 4 which further stabilize the whole structures, the coordinated water molecules in 4 show good thermal stability.

elements.content: The emission spectra of compounds 1−4 in the solid state at room temperature were investigated, as depicted in Figure . Free 3,4′-bpdc ligand also fluoresced in the solid state with the main emission peak at 381 nm upon excitation at 320 nm. For compound 1, both emission bands at 391 and 438 nm were observed, respectively, upon excitation at 338 nm, and the first one displayed a red shift with respect to free bpdc ligand and the second one a blue shift with respect to free dib ligand (λem = 466 nm upon excitation at 377 nm) (). Both the N-donors ligand and O-donors ligand contribute to the fluorescent emission of compound 1 simultaneously. Upon excitation at 325 nm, 2 exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at 408 nm. A clearly red shift occurs in 2 with respect to free bpdc ligand and the coligand phen (λmax = 380 nm with a shoulder at 364 nm upon excitation at 319 nm ( ), which might be attributed to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). The intense blue fluorescent emission in 3 was observed at 442 nm (λex = 340 nm), which could be attributed to the charge transfer between the ligand and metal since free 2,2′-bpy ligand does not show any luminescence in the range of 400−500 nm. Complex 4 exhibits an intense emission peak at 439 nm upon excitation at 320 nm, which means a red shift of ca. 58 nm relative to that of the free 3,4-bpdc (λmax = 381 nm). We tentatively assign it to LMCT.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of compounds 1-4 in the solid state at room temperature were investigated, as depicted in Figure . Free 3,4'-bpdc ligand also fluoresced in the solid state with the main emission peak at 381 nm upon excitation at 320 nm. For compound 1, both emission bands at 391 and 438 nm were observed, respectively, upon excitation at 338 nm, and the first one displayed a red shift with respect to free bpdc ligand and the second one a blue shift with respect to free dib ligand (λem = 466 nm upon excitation at 377 nm) (). Both the N-donors ligand and O-donors ligand contribute to the fluorescent emission of compound 1 simultaneously. Upon excitation at 325 nm, 2 exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at 408 nm. A clearly red shift occurs in 2 with respect to free bpdc ligand and the coligand phen (λmax = 380 nm with a shoulder at 364 nm upon excitation at 319 nm ( ), which might be attributed to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). The intense blue fluorescent emission in 3 was observed at 442 nm (λex = 340 nm), which could be attributed to the charge transfer between the ligand and metal since free 2,2'-bpy ligand does not show any luminescence in the range of 400-500 nm. Complex 4 exhibits an intense emission peak at 439 nm upon excitation at 320 nm, which means a red shift of ca. 58 nm relative to that of the free 3,4-bpdc (λmax = 381 nm). We tentatively assign it to LMCT.

elements.content: Four new Zn(II)/3,4′-bpdc coordination polymers containing different N-donor ancillary coligands (1,4-dib, 1,10-phen, and 2,2-bpy) and without nitrogen ligand were synthesized and characterized. New coordination modes of 3,4-bpdc were founded in the construction of 1−4. Complex 1 shows an interesting novel 2D molecular basketwork, and is self-assembled through π···π stacking and hydrogen-bond interactions to form a 3D supramolecular structure. Complexes 2 and 3 are 1D infinite helical polymeric coordination chains. Complex 4 displays 1D infinite alternating subloop chains and strong hydrogen bonds further make it pack into a 3D supramolecular network. The results of this research illustrate that secondary building ligands play important roles in the self-assembly of final architectures of the prepared coordination ploymers. Furthermore, the strong fluorescent properties of compounds 1−4 at room temperature may make them good candidates for potential photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four new Zn(II)/3,4'-bpdc coordination polymers containing different N-donor ancillary coligands (1,4-dib, 1,10-phen, and 2,2-bpy) and without nitrogen ligand were synthesized and characterized. New coordination modes of 3,4-bpdc were founded in the construction of 1-4. Complex 1 shows an interesting novel 2D molecular basketwork, and is self-assembled through π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and hydrogen-bond interactions to form a 3D supramolecular structure. Complexes 2 and 3 are 1D infinite helical polymeric coordination chains. Complex 4 displays 1D infinite alternating subloop chains and strong hydrogen bonds further make it pack into a 3D supramolecular network. The results of this research illustrate that secondary building ligands play important roles in the self-assembly of final architectures of the prepared coordination ploymers. Furthermore, the strong fluorescent properties of compounds 1-4 at room temperature may make them good candidates for potential photoactive materials.

They were collected and washed with H2O and ethanol, followed by drying in air at room temperature.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA curve (Figure A) of 1 indicates the release of a guest water molecule from 353 to 473 K (observed 1.7%, calcd 1.78%) to give the product of water-free [Zn2(bpdc)2(dib)2], which is stable up to 593 K, implying that the free water molecules could not be released before 473 K due to the hydrogen bonds by free water molecules. Then the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 593−1073 K. The weak interactions and hydrogen bonds between adjacent layers led to 1 to be stable up to 593 K. For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of free water molecules was observed from 303 to 382 K (obsd 6.69%, calcd 6.89%). The anhydrous composition begins to decompose at 593 K (Figure B), which indicates that the 1D chain formulated as Zn(bpdc)(phen) is stable below 593 K. For 3, the first weight loss of 4.12% from 353 to 423 K is in accordance with the loss of a free water molecule (calculated: 4.44%), while the second weight loss of 78.8% from 438 to 1063 K corresponds to the decomposition of 3. Thermogravimetric analyses of 4 revealed that no weight loss appears during 303 to 433 K, and the first weight loss occurs (5.56%) corresponding well to the release of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 5.57%) from 433 to 531 K. Probably due to the existence of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions in compound 4 which further stabilize the whole structures, the coordinated water molecules in 4 show good thermal stability.

Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of compounds 1−4 in the solid state at room temperature were investigated, as depicted in Figure . Free 3,4′-bpdc ligand also fluoresced in the solid state with the main emission peak at 381 nm upon excitation at 320 nm. For compound 1, both emission bands at 391 and 438 nm were observed, respectively, upon excitation at 338 nm, and the first one displayed a red shift with respect to free bpdc ligand and the second one a blue shift with respect to free dib ligand (λem = 466 nm upon excitation at 377 nm) (). Both the N-donors ligand and O-donors ligand contribute to the fluorescent emission of compound 1 simultaneously. Upon excitation at 325 nm, 2 exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at 408 nm. A clearly red shift occurs in 2 with respect to free bpdc ligand and the coligand phen (λmax = 380 nm with a shoulder at 364 nm upon excitation at 319 nm ( ), which might be attributed to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). The intense blue fluorescent emission in 3 was observed at 442 nm (λex = 340 nm), which could be attributed to the charge transfer between the ligand and metal since free 2,2′-bpy ligand does not show any luminescence in the range of 400−500 nm. Complex 4 exhibits an intense emission peak at 439 nm upon excitation at 320 nm, which means a red shift of ca. 58 nm relative to that of the free 3,4-bpdc (λmax = 381 nm). We tentatively assign it to LMCT.
